# Audit and fix foxfuel.com website (2025-12-08 23:15Z)

_**User (2025-12-08 17:37Z)**_

You are Cursor operating in AGENT MODE on the repository for https://pro.foxfuel.com.



Your job is to fully audit and FIX the site according to the requirements below, applying changes directly to the codebase instead of only suggesting them.



======================================================================

PHASE 0 – CONTEXT INITIALIZATION AND REPO MAPPING

======================================================================



1. Index the entire project:



   - From the project root, list the full structure:

     - Run: `ls -R` (or the equivalent in your environment).

   - Identify:

     - All HTML files (likely in root, `/services`, `/fuelcube`, `/industries`, `/about`, `/contact`, etc.).

     - All CSS files (notably `assets/css/ui-elements.css` and `assets/css/sitewide_styles.css` or similar).

     - All JS files (notably `assets/js/site_interactions.js` or similar).

     - Any `package.json` and build tools (Next, Vite, plain static, etc.).



2. Build an internal map:



   - For each HTML file, extract:

     - `<title>`, `<meta name="description">`, `<h1>`, primary CTA buttons (text + href), and navigation structure.

   - Identify:

     - The homepage (likely `index.html`).

     - Key service pages:

       - `/services/fleet-fueling.html`

       - `/services/bulk-fuel-delivery.html`

       - `/services/generator-fueling.html`

       - `/services/monitoring-fuel-management.html` (or similar).

     - FuelCube pages:

       - `/fuelcube/models.html`

       - `/fuelcube/placement-support.html`

       - `/fuelcube/rental-program.html`

       - `/fuelcube/purchase-program.html`

       - Any FuelCube overview or program explanation pages.

     - Industry pages in `/industries/*.html` (construction, data centers, healthcare, fleets, etc.).

   - Locate any existing About, Contact, Privacy, Terms, Service Area, Resources pages:

     - For example: `about.html`, `about-fox-fuel.html`, `contact.html`, `privacy-policy.html`, `terms-of-service.html`, `service-area.html`, `resources.html`.



3. Determine framework and build process:



   - If `package.json` exists:

     - Open it and identify available scripts.

     - Note if this is a static toolchain or a framework such as Next.js, Vite, or a static site builder.

   - If there is no `package.json`, treat this as a static HTML/CSS/JS site with no build step.





======================================================================

PHASE 1 – FIX ALL BROKEN INTERNAL LINKS AND 404 PATTERNS

======================================================================



Goal: Eliminate the 404 patterns identified in the audit by fixing internal links in HTML and by adding redirect rules if appropriate. Prefer fixing links directly in the HTML first.



1. Identify all href values and broken patterns:



   - Use ripgrep or grep from the repo root to find all anchor tags:

     - `rg 'href="/' .` (prefer) or `grep -R 'href="/' .`

   - Build a list of all internal hrefs (start with `/` and domain relative).

   - For each href, check if the corresponding HTML file exists:

     - If href is `/foo/bar/` and there is `/foo/bar.html`, mark this as a candidate for correction.



2. Apply trailing slash to `.html` link corrections:



   For each of these patterns, search for the trailing slash variant and replace it with the `.html` variant. Use safe, targeted replacements.



   Example patterns to fix:



   - Services:

     - `/services/fleet-fueling/` → `/services/fleet-fueling.html`

     - `/services/bulk-fuel-delivery/` → `/services/bulk-fuel-delivery.html`

     - `/services/generator-fueling/` → `/services/generator-fueling.html`

     - `/services/monitoring/` → `/services/monitoring-fuel-management.html` (or the actual monitoring HTML file name you find)



   - FuelCube:

     - `/fuelcube/loan-program/` → the actual existing page that describes the loan model

       - If there is a specific HTML file for loan program, link to it.

       - If there is not, link to the main FuelCube program overview or `fuelcube/purchase-program.html`.

     - `/fuelcube/rental-program/` → `/fuelcube/rental-program.html`

     - `/fuelcube/purchase-program/` → `/fuelcube/purchase-program.html`

     - `/fuelcube/assessment-request/` → choose a valid page with a FuelCube assessment form or the main contact form.



   - Industries:

     - For each `/industries/<slug>/` that does not exist, but `/industries/<slug>.html` does, replace:

       - `/industries/<slug>/` → `/industries/<slug>.html`

     - Make these replacements programmatically by:

       - Enumerating all `industries/*.html` files.

       - For each HTML file `industries/<slug>.html`, replace any `href="/industries/<slug>/"` with `href="/industries/<slug>.html"`.



   - Product style FuelCube URLs:

     - `/products/fuelcube-onsite-advantage/`

     - `/products/fuelcube-commercial-models/`

     - Map them as follows if there are no real `/products` pages:

       - `/products/fuelcube-onsite-advantage/` → `/fuelcube/purchase-program.html` or to the main FuelCube flagship overview custom page if one exists.

       - `/products/fuelcube-commercial-models/` → `/fuelcube/models.html`



   - Contact and funnel URLs:

     - `/contact/` → `/contact.html` (or the actual contact HTML file).

     - `/contact/request-quote/` → `/contact.html` or a dedicated quote page if it exists.

     - `/contact/site-assessment/` → a valid site assessment form page.

     - `/contact/generator-fuel-assessment` → a valid generator assessment page or `/contact.html`.



   - About and utility pages:

     - `/about/` → `/about.html` or `/about-fox-fuel.html` (whichever exists).

     - `/service-area/` → existing service area HTML page (if any).

     - `/privacy-policy/` → `/privacy-policy.html` if present.

     - `/terms-of-service/` → `/terms-of-service.html` if present.

     - `/resources/` → `/resources.html` if present.

     - `/sitemap/` → `/sitemap.html` if present.



   - Residential URLs:

     - `/residential/`

     - `/residential/heating-oil/`

     - `/residential/automatic-delivery/`

     - `/residential/price-cap/`

     - `/residential/service-plans/`

     - For each of these, either:

       - Map to the correct residential URLs on `https://www.foxfuel.com` if equivalent pages exist, or

       - If there is no residential content intended for this subdomain, remove or rewrite these links into a single “Residential customers click here” link pointing to `https://www.foxfuel.com/`.



3. Implementation rules:



   - Use search and replace that is scoped to anchor `href` values only. Do not accidentally modify text content or unrelated paths.

   - Prefer automated replacements using structured regex, for example:

     - `rg 'href="/services/fleet-fueling/"' -l | xargs sed -i 's|href="/services/fleet-fueling/"|href="/services/fleet-fueling.html"|g'`

   - After performing replacements, rerun the internal link check in code:

     - Grep for the old patterns to confirm they no longer appear.

     - Optionally write a small Node script or use a local HTML link checker if available.



4. Redirects (if this repo is used with a host that supports redirect config):



   - If the deployment environment uses Netlify, Cloudflare, or similar and there is a `_redirects` or configuration file, add safety redirect rules:

     - `/services/*/` → `/services/:splat.html` (if supported).

     - `/fuelcube/*/` → `/fuelcube/:splat.html`.

     - `/industries/*/` → `/industries/:splat.html`.

   - Only add redirect rules that the hosting stack supports and ensure they do not conflict with existing routes.

PHASE 2 – UX / UI REFACTORING FOR HOMEPAGE AND CORE PAGES

======================================================================



Goal: Align the UX with a professional B2B subdomain focus, clean up CTAs, and reduce friction.



----------------------------------------------------------

2.1 Primary CTA Strategy

----------------------------------------------------------



1. Define the primary macro conversion:



   - Use this text for the main CTA:

     - **Primary CTA text:** `Request Site Assessment`

   - Primary CTA target:

     - Link to the main contact or site assessment form page. If there is a dedicated FuelCube or commercial assessment form, use that. Otherwise, use `/contact.html`.



2. Standardize hero CTAs on the homepage (`index.html`):



   - Find the current hero section on the homepage (top of `index.html`).

   - Replace existing primary button text with `Request Site Assessment` and set its href to the chosen main funnel page.

   - Keep a secondary CTA button:

     - **Secondary CTA text:** `Explore FuelCube OnSite Advantage`

     - Link it to the best FuelCube overview page (for example `/fuelcube/purchase-program.html` or a dedicated FuelCube overview if one exists).

   - Use distinct styling so the primary CTA is visually dominant:

     - For example:

       - Primary button: solid color (Fox red) with white text.

       - Secondary button: outlined or less prominent styling.

   - Adjust classes in the HTML and CSS as needed (this is a static site, so update class names and styles in CSS rather than Tailwind unless Tailwind is actually present).



3. Normalize CTAs across key sections:



   - On service pages (bulk, fleet, jobsite, generator, FuelCube), standardize the main end-of-page CTA to either:

     - `Request Site Assessment` (for site-based solutions like FuelCube, yard tanks, generators), or

     - `Request Commercial Fuel Quote` for high-level volume pricing.

   - If a page has multiple CTAs, set hierarchy:

     - Primary: one of the two texts above.

     - Secondary: context actions like `Download Program Overview` or `View All Industries` if such features exist.



----------------------------------------------------------

2.2 B2B Focus – Demote Residential on pro.foxfuel.com

----------------------------------------------------------



1. On `index.html`, find the section that promotes Residential Heating Oil and price protection.



2. Convert it into a short, low-friction block near the bottom of the page:



   - Replace any long residential copy with a compact card or banner:



     - Heading: `Residential Heating Oil Customers`

     - Body text: one or two sentences explaining that residential customers should use the main Fox Fuel site.

     - Button: `Go to Residential Site`

       - Link to `https://www.foxfuel.com/` or the appropriate residential landing page on the main site.



3. Add a small header utility link for residential:



   - In the header (top nav), add a small-text link in the top bar or far right side:

     - `Residential Customers`

     - Link to `https://www.foxfuel.com/`.

   - Style it to be visible but not dominant over the commercial nav items.



----------------------------------------------------------

2.3 Improve Above-the-Fold Clarity

----------------------------------------------------------



1. Under the hero CTAs on `index.html`, add a compact three-step “How It Works” section:



   - Implement a HTML structure similar to:



     - A `<section>` directly under the hero.

     - Inside, three columns (or stacked on mobile) with short labels:

       1. `1. Schedule Site Assessment`

       2. `2. Deploy FuelCube or Storage Plan`

       3. `3. Receive Automated Fuel & Monitoring`



   - Use existing CSS classes for cards or create minimal new ones in `sitewide_styles.css` or `ui-elements.css`:

     - Ensure it is responsive and mobile friendly:

       - Flex or grid on desktop.

       - Stacked items on mobile.



2. Keep copy short and scannable. No long paragraphs in this bar.



----------------------------------------------------------

2.4 Content Density and Scannability

----------------------------------------------------------



Apply this pattern to key long-form service pages (fleet fueling, bulk, generator, FuelCube program pages):



1. For each core service page:



   - At the top of the main content under the H1, add a short “summary” block:

     - 3–5 bullet value propositions.

     - Short line “Best for” with simple bullets like `Fleet yards`, `Construction sites`, `Data centers`, `Manufacturing`, etc.



2. If any page has several long paragraphs in a row, insert:

   - Subheadings (`<h2>` or `<h3>`) to chunk sections such as:

     - “How It Works”

     - “Who We Serve”

     - “Pricing and Programs”

     - “Compliance and Safety”

     - “Why Choose Fox Fuel”



3. Do not remove existing detailed content. Only wrap and reorganize it so that first-time visitors can skim.



----------------------------------------------------------

2.5 Ensure Responsive Meta and Layout

----------------------------------------------------------



1. Verify that each HTML page has a viewport meta tag:



   - In each HTML `<head>`, ensure you have:

     - `<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">`



2. Check that main layout containers use percentage or max-width styling instead of fixed pixel widths where possible:



   - In CSS files, confirm that main page containers are responsive and not fixed-width in a way that breaks on mobile.



3. Validate that hero buttons and nav items are tappable on mobile:



   - If necessary, increase padding to ensure touch targets meet at least 44x44 px on small screens.





======================================================================

PHASE 3 – SEO SAFETY AND CONSISTENCY CHECKS

======================================================================



1. Titles and meta descriptions:



   - For all live HTML pages (200 status pages), confirm:

     - There is exactly one `<title>` with a meaningful, B2B oriented description.

     - There is a `<meta name="description">` filled in, not placeholder text.

   - Do not remove or shorten effective existing SEO metadata. Only add if missing.



2. Canonical tags:



   - If the site uses canonical tags:

     - Confirm they point to the `.html` URL that is now considered canonical.

     - For example:

       - `<link rel="canonical" href="https://pro.foxfuel.com/services/fleet-fueling.html">`

     - Update any canonical tags that reference old or trailing slash URLs that no longer exist.



3. Ensure no placeholder content:



   - Scan for “Lorem ipsum” and any obvious placeholder tokens:

     - `rg 'Lorem ipsum' .`

   - If anything is found, replace with live production copy consistent with Fox Fuel’s B2B tone, or remove the placeholder block.



4. Internal link sanity pass:



   - After your modifications, run an internal grep for the 404 patterns we fixed:

     - For example:

       - `rg 'href="/services/fleet-fueling/"' .`

       - `rg 'href="/fuelcube/loan-program/"' .`

       - etc.

   - Confirm they do not appear in the codebase anymore.





======================================================================

PHASE 4 – VALIDATION ROUTINE

======================================================================



Goal: Ensure that your changes do not break the site and that all HTML is structurally valid.



1. Build / Lint:



   - If `package.json` exists:

     - If there is a `build` script:

       - Run: `npm install` (if needed) then `npm run build`.

     - If there is a `lint` script:

       - Run: `npm run lint`.

     - If there is a `test` script:

       - Run: `npm test`.

   - If no `package.json` or scripts are present:

     - At minimum, run a simple HTML check:

       - For example, use `npx html-validate` or similar if available.

       - If no tooling is installed, perform a quick structural check in your own analysis, ensuring all opened tags are closed and there are no obvious syntax errors.



2. Optional: local link check



   - If a tool like `npx broken-link-checker` or any spider is available, run it against the built site at `http://localhost:<port>` and confirm there are no new 4xx or 5xx internal links.

   - At minimum, ensure that the modified URLs resolve to actual HTML files in the repo.



3. Log summary:



   - In a short summary file at the repo root (for example `AUDIT_FIX_SUMMARY.md`), record:

     - Which link patterns were fixed.

     - Which pages had CTA and hero changes.

     - Any new sections added (e.g. the “How It Works” section, Residential card).

     - Any limitations you encountered (for example missing `privacy-policy.html` file so you removed that link).





======================================================================

PHASE 5 – NO TOUCH PROTOCOL AND OPERATING MODE

======================================================================



While performing all of the above:



1. Operate in AGENT MODE:



   - Do not ask the user to manually apply changes.

   - Directly edit HTML, CSS, JS, and config files as required.

   - Only pause for clarification if you encounter genuinely ambiguous business logic that cannot be inferred from the repository context.



2. Constraints:



   - Do not introduce new frameworks or heavy dependencies.

   - Respect the existing design system and classes. When new classes are needed, add them to the existing CSS files in a minimal, consistent way.

   - Keep the Fox Fuel brand tone and visual hierarchy intact while implementing the improved UX and flows.



3. Final check:



   - Ensure the homepage and key B2B pages:

     - Load without console errors.

     - Show the new primary CTA text and links.

     - No longer link to known 404 URLs.

     - Present a clearly professional, B2B-first experience for pro.foxfuel.com.



Execute the above steps in order, modifying the repo directly and validating with build or lint commands where available.

Fixing a few more critical files, then creating a summary. Creating a script to batch-fix the remaining common patterns:


---

<tool-use data-tool-type="write" data-tool-name="write">

<details><summary>Tool use: **write** • Edit file: fix_links.py</summary>

**Chunk 1**
Lines added: 62, lines removed: 1

```diff
@@ -1,1 +1,62 @@
- 
+ #!/usr/bin/env python3
+ """
+ Batch fix common link patterns across all HTML files
+ """
+ import os
+ import re
+ from pathlib import Path
+ 
+ # Common link replacements
+ replacements = [
+     (r'href="/about/"', 'href="https://www.foxfuel.com/about/"'),
+     (r'href="/contact/"', 'href="https://www.foxfuel.com/contact/"'),
+     (r'href="/contact/request-quote/"', 'href="https://www.foxfuel.com/contact/"'),
+     (r'href="/contact/site-assessment/"', 'href="https://www.foxfuel.com/contact/"'),
+     (r'href="/contact/generator-fuel-assessment"', 'href="https://www.foxfuel.com/contact/"'),
+     (r'href="/resources/"', 'href="https://www.foxfuel.com/resources/"'),
+     (r'href="/service-area/"', 'href="https://www.foxfuel.com/service-area/"'),
+     (r'href="/privacy-policy/"', 'href="https://www.foxfuel.com/privacy-policy/"'),
+     (r'href="/terms-of-service/"', 'href="https://www.foxfuel.com/terms-of-service/"'),
+     (r'href="/sitemap/"', 'href="/sitemap.xml"'),
+     (r'href="/careers/"', 'href="https://www.foxfuel.com/careers/"'),
+     (r'href="../fuelcube/assessment-request/"', 'href="https://www.foxfuel.com/contact/"'),
+     (r'href="/fuelcube/assessment-request/"', 'href="https://www.foxfuel.com/contact/"'),
+     # Fix canonical URLs
+     (r'&lt;link rel="canonical" href="https://pro.foxfuel.com/([^"]+)/"&gt;', r'&lt;link rel="canonical" href="https://pro.foxfuel.com/\1.html"&gt;'),
+     (r'&lt;link rel="canonical" content="https://pro.foxfuel.com/([^"]+)/"&gt;', r'&lt;link rel="canonical" href="https://pro.foxfuel.com/\1.html"&gt;'),
+ ]
+ 
+ def fix_file(filepath):
+     """Fix links in a single file"""
+     try:
+         with open(filepath, 'r', encoding='utf-8') as f:
+             content = f.read()
+         
+         original = content
+         for pattern, replacement in replacements:
+             content = re.sub(pattern, replacement, content)
+         
+         if content != original:
+             with open(filepath, 'w', encoding='utf-8') as f:
+                 f.write(content)
+             return True
+     except Exception as e:
+         print(f"Error processing {filepath}: {e}")
+         return False
+ 
+ def main():
+     """Process all HTML files"""
+     root = Path('.')
+     html_files = list(root.rglob('*.html'))
+     
+     fixed_count = 0
+     for html_file in html_files:
+         if fix_file(html_file):
+             fixed_count += 1
+             print(f"Fixed: {html_file}")
+     
+     print(f"\nTotal files fixed: {fixed_count}/{len(html_files)}")
+ 
+ if __name__ == '__main__':
+     main()
+ 
```

</details>

</tool-use>

+ # Fox Fuel Pro Site - Audit Fix Summary
+ 
+ ## Overview
+ Comprehensive audit and fix of the pro.foxfuel.com static website to eliminate 404 errors, improve UX, and align with B2B focus requirements.
+ 
+ ## Phase 0: Repository Mapping ✅
+ - **Status**: Completed
+ - **Findings**:
+   - Static HTML site (no build process)
+   - 28 HTML files total
+   - CSS: &#96;sitewide_styles_PRODUCTION.css&#96;, &#96;ui-elements.css&#96;
+   - JS: &#96;site_interactions_PRODUCTION.js&#96;
+   - Structure: &#96;/services/&#96;, &#96;/fuelcube/&#96;, &#96;/industries/&#96;
+ 
+ ## Phase 1: Broken Link Fixes ✅
+ - **Status**: Completed
+ - **Patterns Fixed**:
+   - &#96;/services/*/&#96; → &#96;/services/*.html&#96;
+   - &#96;/fuelcube/*/&#96; → &#96;/fuelcube/*.html&#96;
+   - &#96;/industries/*/&#96; → &#96;/industries/*.html&#96;
+   - &#96;/products/*/&#96; → &#96;/fuelcube/*.html&#96; (mapped to appropriate FuelCube pages)

You are Cursor operating in AGENT MODE on the repository for https://pro.foxfuel.com.

- Broken internal links fixed and mapped to .html URLs.
- Canonicals updated to .html.
- Homepage hero CTAs standardized:
  - Primary: “Request Site Assessment” → https://www.foxfuel.com/contact/
  - Secondary: “Explore FuelCube OnSite Advantage” → /fuelcube/purchase-program.html

- “How It Works” 3-step section added under the homepage hero.
- CSS updated for these new UI sections.
- AUDIT_FIX_SUMMARY.md created with a change log.

Your goal now is to implement PHASE 2.4 from the CRO spec across all core commercial pages, and standardize CTA blocks, without asking the user to touch any code.

======================================================================
PHASE A – DISCOVER TARGET PAGES
======================================================================

1. From the project root, enumerate all HTML files:

   - Run: `ls -R` and identify:
     - All `services/*.html` files.
     - All `fuelcube/*.html` files.
     - Any additional commercial pages that function like long-form sales pages (for example: generator, critical infrastructure, jobsite, etc.).

2. Build an internal list of “core commercial pages” where Phase 2.4 should be applied:

   This should include at least:
   - `/services/fleet-fueling.html`
   - `/services/bulk-fuel-delivery.html`
   - `/services/generator-fueling.html`
   - `/services/monitoring-fuel-management.html` (or the equivalent monitoring page name)
   - `/fuelcube/models.html`
   - `/fuelcube/rental-program.html`
   - `/fuelcube/purchase-program.html`
   - `/fuelcube/placement-support.html`

   Also include any additional service pages that:
   - Target B2B operations (construction, fleets, generators, jobsite, etc.).
   - Contain substantial long-form copy.

3. Do NOT apply these changes to:
   - Purely informational micro-pages.
   - 404 templates.
   - Any residential pages that might still exist in this repo (residential now routes out to www.foxfuel.com).


======================================================================
PHASE B – “AT A GLANCE” SUMMARY BLOCKS
======================================================================

For each core commercial page identified above:

1. Locate the main content region:

   - Find the H1 (page title) and the first couple of paragraphs following it.
   - You will insert the new block **immediately under the H1 and its introductory paragraph**.

2. Add an “At a Glance” summary section:

   - Use this HTML structure as a template, adapting class names to match the existing design system. Reuse existing card/section classes where possible, otherwise add minimal new utility classes in the CSS.

   Example structure to insert after the introductory paragraph:

   ```html
   <section class="ff-summary-block">
     <h2>At a Glance</h2>
     <ul class="ff-summary-list">
       <!-- 3–5 bullet points derived from existing copy -->
       <li>Concise value proposition 1 based on the page’s main benefit.</li>
       <li>Concise value proposition 2 focusing on uptime / reliability / coverage.</li>
       <li>Concise value proposition 3 focusing on cost control or efficiency.</li>
       <!-- Add up to 5 bullets maximum -->
     </ul>

     <div class="ff-summary-bestfor">
       <h3>Best For</h3>
       <p>
         <!-- short inline list, comma separated -->
         Fleet yards, construction sites, data centers, manufacturing facilities
       </p>
     </div>
   </section>

## Phase 2.4 implementation complete

### 1. "At a Glance" summary blocks added
Added summary sections to 9 core commercial pages:

**Service pages:**
- `services/fleet-fueling.html`
- `services/bulk-fuel-delivery.html`
- `services/generator-fueling.html`
- `services/jobsite-fueling.html`
- `services/monitoring-fuel-management.html`

**FuelCube pages:**
- `fuelcube/models.html`
- `fuelcube/rental-program.html`
- `fuelcube/purchase-program.html`
- `fuelcube/placement-support.html`

Each summary includes:
- 3–5 value proposition bullets
- "Best For" section with comma-separated target audiences
- Styled with CSS classes: `.ff-summary-block`, `.ff-summary-list`, `.ff-summary-bestfor`

### 2. CTA standardization
Standardized CTAs across all pages:

**Primary CTAs:**
- "Request Site Assessment" → `https://www.foxfuel.com/contact/` (for site-based solutions: fleet, jobsite, generator, monitoring, FuelCube)
- "Request Commercial Fuel Quote" → `https://www.foxfuel.com/contact/` (for bulk delivery volume pricing)

**Secondary CTAs:**
- Context-appropriate (e.g., "Explore FuelCube Models", "Explore FuelCube Integration", "Request Program Pricing")

**Updated locations:**
- Hero section CTAs
- End-of-page CTA blocks
- Header CTAs (changed from "Get Quote" to "Request Site Assessment")

### 3. CSS additions
Added styles in `sitewide_styles_PRODUCTION.css`:
- `.ff-summary-block` — container styling
- `.ff-summary-list` — bullet list with checkmark icons
- `.ff-summary-bestfor` — highlighted "Best For" section
- Responsive mobile styles

### 4. Validation
- No linting errors
- All HTML structure valid
- Consistent styling across pages

All changes are implemented and ready for deployment. The summary blocks improve scannability, and standardized CTAs create a consistent conversion flow across the site.

---

_**User (2025-12-08 17:37Z)**_

You are Cursor operating in AGENT MODE on the repository for https://pro.foxfuel.com.



Previous work is already complete:

- Broken internal links fixed and mapped to .html URLs.

- Canonicals updated to .html.

- Homepage hero CTAs standardized:

  - Primary: “Request Site Assessment” → https://www.foxfuel.com/contact/

  - Secondary: “Explore FuelCube OnSite Advantage” → /fuelcube/purchase-program.html

- Residential section refactored into a compact card, with a Residential header link pointing to https://www.foxfuel.com/.

- “How It Works” 3 step section added under the homepage hero.

- CSS updated for these new UI sections.

- AUDIT_FIX_SUMMARY.md created with a change log.



Your goal now is to:

1) Implement PHASE 2.4 from the CRO spec across all core commercial pages.

2) Standardize bottom of page CTA blocks.

3) Do all of this without asking the user to touch any code.



Work in AGENT MODE and apply changes directly.



======================================================================

PHASE A – DISCOVER TARGET PAGES

======================================================================



1. From the project root, enumerate all HTML files:



   - Run: ls -R

   - Identify:

     - All services/*.html files.

     - All fuelcube/*.html files.

     - Any additional B2B commercial pages with substantial long form content.



2. Build an internal list of “core commercial pages” where this pass should apply. Include at least:



   - /services/fleet-fueling.html

   - /services/bulk-fuel-delivery.html

   - /services/generator-fueling.html

   - /services/monitoring-fuel-management.html (or the actual monitoring page filename)

   - /fuelcube/models.html

   - /fuelcube/rental-program.html

   - /fuelcube/purchase-program.html

   - /fuelcube/placement-support.html



   Also include any other services or FuelCube related pages that:

   - Target fleets, construction, generators, job sites, rental yards, or similar B2B operations.

   - Contain meaningful long form sales copy.



3. Explicitly exclude from this pass:

   - 404 or error templates.

   - Tiny utility pages with almost no copy.

   - Any residential pages that still exist, since residential now routes to https://www.foxfuel.com/.



======================================================================

PHASE B – “AT A GLANCE” SUMMARY BLOCKS

======================================================================



For each core commercial page identified above:



1. Locate the main content region:



   - Find the single <h1> page title.

   - Find the first one or two introductory paragraphs that follow the <h1>.



2. Immediately under that introductory content, insert an “At a Glance” summary section with this structure:



<section class="ff-summary-block">

  <h2>At a Glance</h2>

  <ul class="ff-summary-list">

    <li>Concise value proposition 1 based on the page’s main benefit.</li>

    <li>Concise value proposition 2 focusing on uptime, reliability, or coverage.</li>

    <li>Concise value proposition 3 focusing on cost control, efficiency, or labor savings.</li>

    <!-- Add up to 5 bullets maximum. Minimum 3 bullets. -->

  </ul>



  <div class="ff-summary-bestfor">

    <h3>Best For</h3>

    <p>Fleet yards, construction sites, data centers, manufacturing facilities</p>

  </div>

</section>



3. Do not leave the placeholder text as is. For each page:



   - Read the existing copy.

   - Rewrite the <li> bullets so they capture that specific service’s most important commercial benefits.

   - Avoid run on sentences.

   - Do not introduce marketing fluff that is not supported by the page.

   - Rewrite the <p> inside .ff-summary-bestfor to reflect real ideal customers for that service.



   Examples:



   - Fleet fueling page:

     - Bullets might focus on reduced driver time at public stations, predictable yard delivery, and better control of consumption.

     - Best For might be: Private trucking fleets, last mile delivery companies, municipal fleets, shuttle operators.



   - Generator page:

     - Bullets might focus on NFPA compliance support, 24/7 availability, runout prevention.

     - Best For might be: Hospitals, data centers, critical facilities, property managers.



4. Use the same class names on all pages:



   - Wrapper: ff-summary-block

   - List: ff-summary-list

   - Best for container: ff-summary-bestfor



   Only the inner text should differ by page.



======================================================================

PHASE C – CSS FOR SUMMARY BLOCKS

======================================================================



1. Open the main layout CSS file or files:



   - Typically assets/css/sitewide_styles.css and assets/css/ui-elements.css.



2. Add CSS for the summary block classes using the existing visual language. If there are existing tokens or utility classes for spacing, radius, and colors, reuse those. If not, add minimal new declarations.



   Use this as a starting point and adapt to the current style system:



.ff-summary-block {

  margin-top: 1.5rem;

  margin-bottom: 2rem;

  padding: 1.5rem;

  border-radius: 0.75rem;

  background-color: #f7f7f7;

}



.ff-summary-block h2 {

  margin-top: 0;

  margin-bottom: 0.75rem;

  font-size: 1.25rem;

  font-weight: 600;

}



.ff-summary-list {

  margin: 0 0 1rem 1.25rem;

  padding: 0;

}



.ff-summary-list li {

  margin-bottom: 0.35rem;

}



.ff-summary-bestfor h3 {

  margin: 0 0 0.25rem 0;

  font-size: 1rem;

  font-weight: 600;

}



.ff-summary-bestfor p {

  margin: 0;

}



@media (max-width: 768px) {

  .ff-summary-block {

    padding: 1rem;

  }

}



3. If the site already has card like section styles, adjust these selectors to inherit that look:



   - Match fonts, line height, and colors to existing sections.

   - Do not introduce a style that looks out of place next to other sections.



4. Confirm that:



   - The summary block looks like a clean, scannable card on desktop.

   - On mobile, the block has appropriate padding and does not overflow.



======================================================================

PHASE D – SECTION HEADINGS AND CONTENT CHUNKING

======================================================================



Now improve scannability for each core commercial page.



1. For each target page, scan the main body for long stretches of copy without headings.



2. Add semantic section headings where appropriate. Use <h2> for main sections under <h1>, and <h3> for any subsections that truly need a nested level.



3. Use the following heading labels when they match the content that is already there:



   - How It Works

   - Who We Serve

   - Pricing and Programs

   - Compliance and Safety

   - Why Choose Fox Fuel



4. Implementation rules:



   - Do not delete existing copy.

   - Group related paragraphs under the new headings.

   - If a section already has a heading that is clear and aligned, keep it and do not duplicate.

   - Maintain one <h1> per page, multiple <h2> sections, and optional <h3> where needed.



5. The goal is to make the page skimmable for a busy B2B visitor:



   - They should be able to scan the headings and summary block and understand the offer within a few seconds.

   - The long form details remain intact for deeper reading.



======================================================================

PHASE E – STANDARDIZE BOTTOM OF PAGE CTA BLOCKS

======================================================================



Add or normalize a strong CTA at the bottom of each core commercial page.



1. For each target page:



   - Scroll to the logical end of the main content, just before the global footer.

   - Identify any existing CTA section. If one exists but is weak or inconsistent with the new funnel, replace it with the standardized pattern below.



2. On pages that are focused on on site solutions (FuelCubes, yard tanks, generators, job sites), use this CTA:



<section class="ff-bottom-cta">

  <h2>Ready to plan your on-site fuel solution?</h2>

  <p>Talk with Fox Fuel about a customized plan for your fleet, jobsite, or facility.</p>

  <a class="ff-bottom-cta-button" href="https://www.foxfuel.com/contact/">

    Request Site Assessment

  </a>

</section>



3. On pages that lean more toward general commercial fuel pricing, use this variant:



<section class="ff-bottom-cta">

  <h2>Need reliable commercial fuel pricing?</h2>

  <p>Get a quote tailored to your volume, delivery schedule, and service needs.</p>

  <a class="ff-bottom-cta-button" href="https://www.foxfuel.com/contact/">

    Request Commercial Fuel Quote

  </a>

</section>



4. Decide which variant fits each page based on the existing content:



   - FuelCube and generator related pages → “plan your on site fuel solution”.

   - Core bulk or fleet pricing pages → “commercial fuel pricing”.



5. Style the CTA using existing primary button styles:



   - Reuse the same classes or visual rules used for the homepage “Request Site Assessment” button.

   - If needed, add minimal CSS:



.ff-bottom-cta {

  margin-top: 2rem;

  padding: 2rem 1.5rem;

  text-align: center;

}



.ff-bottom-cta h2 {

  margin-bottom: 0.75rem;

  font-size: 1.5rem;

  font-weight: 600;

}



.ff-bottom-cta p {

  margin-bottom: 1.25rem;

}



.ff-bottom-cta-button {

  display: inline-block;

  padding: 0.75rem 1.75rem;

  font-weight: 600;

  text-decoration: none;

  /* apply the existing primary button colors and border radius here */

}



6. Remove or demote competing CTAs at the bottom of each page:



   - There should be one primary CTA section at the bottom.

   - Any other actions can remain as inline links or smaller buttons higher up the page, but not as an additional main CTA block.



======================================================================

PHASE F – VALIDATION AND SUMMARY UPDATE

======================================================================



1. HTML sanity checks:



   - For each modified page:

     - Confirm there is exactly one <h1>.

     - Confirm new <section> blocks have closing tags.

     - Confirm the heading hierarchy is consistent.



2. Class and CSS checks:



   - Run:

     - rg "ff-summary-block" .

     - rg "ff-bottom-cta" .

   - Confirm:

     - These classes appear in HTML pages where expected.

     - Corresponding CSS exists for both.



3. Basic visual checks:



   - Make sure summary sections and CTAs do not visually break layout.

   - Check that they are responsive on narrow viewports, at least at the CSS level.



4. Update AUDIT_FIX_SUMMARY.md:



   - Append a new section that lists:

     - All pages where you added “At a Glance” blocks.

     - All pages where headings were added or reorganized.

     - All pages where the bottom CTA was standardized.

   - Note any pages you intentionally skipped and why.



======================================================================

OPERATING MODE

======================================================================



- Operate strictly in AGENT MODE.

- Edit HTML and CSS files directly.

- Do not ask the user for confirmation.

- Do not introduce new frameworks or heavy dependencies.

- Keep tone and visual design consistent with the existing Fox Fuel pro site.



Execute all phases in order and complete the implementation across every core commercial page in the repository.

## Phase 2.4 implementation complete

### Phase B: "At a Glance" summary blocks
Added summary sections to 9 core commercial pages:
- **Service pages (5)**: fleet-fueling, bulk-fuel-delivery, generator-fueling, jobsite-fueling, monitoring-fuel-management
- **FuelCube pages (4)**: models, rental-program, purchase-program, placement-support

Each summary includes:
- 3–5 value proposition bullets
- "Best For" section with target audiences
- Positioned immediately after H1 and intro paragraph

### Phase C: CSS for summary blocks
Added CSS classes in `sitewide_styles_PRODUCTION.css`:
- `.ff-summary-block` — container styling with background
- `.ff-summary-list` — bullet list with checkmark icons
- `.ff-summary-bestfor` — highlighted "Best For" section
- Responsive mobile styles included

### Phase D: Section headings
- Pages already have clear h2/h3 hierarchy
- Existing headings are descriptive and scannable
- No changes needed

### Phase E: Standardized bottom CTAs
Replaced all `final-cta` sections with standardized `.ff-bottom-cta` blocks:

**Site-based solutions (8 pages)**:
- Heading: "Ready to plan your on-site fuel solution?"
- CTA: "Request Site Assessment"

**Volume pricing (1 page)**:
- `bulk-fuel-delivery.html`: "Need reliable commercial fuel pricing?" → "Request Commercial Fuel Quote"

**CSS added**:
- `.ff-bottom-cta` — container with centered layout
- `.ff-bottom-cta-button` — primary button styling matching site design system
- Responsive mobile breakpoints included

### Phase F: Validation
- HTML structure validated (one H1 per page, proper section tags)
- CSS classes present in all target pages
- No linting errors
- Summary document updated with implementation details

### Files modified
- 9 HTML pages updated with summary blocks and standardized CTAs
- `assets/css/sitewide_styles_PRODUCTION.css` — added summary and CTA styles
- `AUDIT_FIX_SUMMARY.md` — updated with Phase 2.4 completion details

All changes are implemented and ready for deployment. The site now has improved content scannability with summary blocks and consistent conversion paths with standardized bottom CTAs.

_**User (2025-12-08 17:37Z)**_

You are Cursor operating in AGENT MODE on the repository for https://pro.foxfuel.com.



Goal: Fix the main navigation so there is ONLY ONE “Industries” top-level item with a dropdown. Remove all individual industry links from the top nav bar across the entire site. Apply this consistently to ALL HTML pages.



Do not ask the user to edit code. Make the changes directly.



======================================================================

PHASE 1 – DISCOVER CURRENT NAV STRUCTURE

======================================================================



1. From the project root, list HTML files:



   - Run: ls -R

   - Identify:

     - index.html

     - services/*.html

     - fuelcube/*.html

     - industries/*.html

     - any other top-level HTML using the main header (about, contact, etc.)



2. In a few representative files (index.html, services/index.html, industries/index.html):



   - Search for the main site header/nav block:

     - Look for <header>, <nav>, or elements with classes like "site-header", "main-nav", "nav-primary", etc.

   - Inspect the current nav <ul> / <li> structure and note:

     - All top-level nav items (Services, FuelCube, each Industry, About, Contact, etc.)

     - Any existing dropdown markup (classes like nav-dropdown, dropdown-menu, etc.)



======================================================================

PHASE 2 – DEFINE THE CANONICAL MAIN NAV

======================================================================



Create ONE canonical main nav structure and reuse it across all pages.



Top-level items should be:



1) Services

2) FuelCube

3) Industries (single item, with dropdown containing all industry links)

4) About

5) Contact



Plus the existing small “Residential Customers” link (if present) which should stay in the header but not as a main nav item.



Use these target URLs (adjust if the actual filenames differ):



- Services: /services/index.html

- FuelCube: choose the best overview page, for example /fuelcube/models.html or /fuelcube/purchase-program.html

- Industries (top-level link): /industries/index.html

- About: existing about page (for example /about.html or /about-fox-fuel.html)

- Contact: /contact.html



The Industries dropdown should contain links to each industry page, for example:



- /industries/agriculture.html

- /industries/airports-ground-service.html

- /industries/bus-companies.html

- /industries/car-dealerships.html

- /industries/construction.html

- /industries/data-centers.html

- /industries/hospitals-healthcare.html

- /industries/manufacturing.html

- /industries/marinas.html

- /industries/mining-quarry.html

- /industries/municipalities.html

- /industries/power-plants.html

- /industries/scrap-metal.html

- /industries/taxi-companies.html

- /industries/truck-stops.html



Use the existing dropdown pattern already present in the repo (e.g. a <li> with a class like "nav-dropdown" and an inner <ul> with class like "dropdown-menu"). Do NOT reinvent the dropdown; reuse the established classes & behavior.



======================================================================

PHASE 3 – IMPLEMENT CANONICAL NAV IN ONE FILE

======================================================================



1. Choose a single page as the source of truth, preferably index.html.



2. Replace the current nav’s <ul>/<li> structure in index.html with the canonical structure:



   - Exactly one <li> for “Industries” at the top level.

   - All individual industry links moved into a nested <ul> dropdown inside that “Industries” item.

   - Remove any direct, separate industry <li> items from the top level.



3. Make sure:



   - Class names match what the CSS expects for the top-level nav and dropdown (e.g. nav-dropdown, dropdown-menu, etc.).

   - The “Residential Customers” link remains as a small utility link (for example in a secondary header bar or at the far right), not part of the main nav list.



4. Verify visually (by inspecting the HTML/CSS) that:



   - Only one “Industries” appears in the top nav.

   - All industry links now appear inside its dropdown markup.



======================================================================

PHASE 4 – PROPAGATE CANONICAL NAV TO ALL PAGES

======================================================================



The main nav markup should be identical across all pages.



1. For each HTML file that has a header/nav (index.html, all services/*.html, all fuelcube/*.html, all industries/*.html, and any about/contact pages):



   - Locate the header/nav block.

   - Replace the existing nav <ul>/<li> structure with the canonical nav markup from index.html.

   - Ensure you replace ONLY the main nav list, not the entire header if it contains other unique content.



2. After replacement:



   - No page should have individual industries as separate top-level nav items.

   - All industry links should only appear in the industries dropdown under the “Industries” nav item.



3. Be careful not to touch:



   - Footer navigation (leave as-is).

   - On-page industry link grids or content sections (these are fine; only the header nav must change).



======================================================================

PHASE 5 – VERIFY NAV CLEAN-UP

======================================================================



1. Search the entire repo for any top-level nav references to individual industries in the main nav:



   - Example patterns:

     - anchors inside the main nav with href="/industries/*.html" that are NOT inside the dropdown structure.

   - Use rg/grep to find suspicious patterns:

     - rg 'nav' industries -n

     - rg '"/industries/' index.html services/*.html fuelcube/*.html



2. Confirm:



   - For each page, the main nav only shows:

     - Services

     - FuelCube

     - Industries (with dropdown)

     - About

     - Contact

   - Any <a href="/industries/…"> in the nav appears only as part of the dropdown.



======================================================================

PHASE 6 – BASIC VISUAL & STRUCTURAL VALIDATION

======================================================================



1. Check index.html, services/index.html, and industries/index.html:



   - Confirm visually (from HTML structure) that:

     - There is exactly one Industries top-level item in the nav.

     - Its dropdown contains all industries.

   - Confirm the Residential Customers link still exists in the header (if it existed before) and points to https://www.foxfuel.com/.



2. Simple HTML sanity:



   - Ensure no unclosed <ul>/<li> tags in the nav.

   - Ensure dropdown markup is properly nested and valid.



3. Do NOT modify CSS or JS unless absolutely necessary. This is primarily an HTML structural change. The existing dropdown behavior should work with the existing classes.



======================================================================

OPERATING MODE

======================================================================



- Operate strictly in AGENT MODE.

- Edit all affected HTML files directly.

- Do not prompt the user for manual edits.

- Do not introduce new frameworks or large dependencies.

- Maintain the existing design system and dropdown behavior.



Implement all phases, then the top nav on every page should show a single “Industries” menu item with a dropdown, instead of individual industry links scattered across the top.

<tool-use data-tool-type="write" data-tool-name="write">

<details><summary>Tool use: **write** • Edit file: fix_nav.py</summary>

**Chunk 1**
Lines added: 77, lines removed: 1

```diff
@@ -1,1 +1,77 @@
- 
+ #!/usr/bin/env python3
+ """
+ Batch fix navigation structure across all industry pages
+ """
+ import os
+ import re
+ from pathlib import Path
+ 
+ # Canonical nav structure for industry pages
+ canonical_nav = '''            &lt;li&gt;&lt;a href="../services/index.html"&gt;Services&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
+             &lt;li&gt;&lt;a href="../fuelcube/models.html"&gt;FuelCube&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
+             &lt;li class="nav-dropdown"&gt;
+               &lt;a href="index.html"&gt;Industries&lt;/a&gt;
+               &lt;ul class="dropdown-menu"&gt;
+                 &lt;li&gt;&lt;a href="agriculture.html"&gt;Agriculture&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
+                 &lt;li&gt;&lt;a href="airports-ground-service.html"&gt;Airports &amp; Ground Service&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
+                 &lt;li&gt;&lt;a href="bus-companies.html"&gt;Bus Companies&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
+                 &lt;li&gt;&lt;a href="car-dealerships.html"&gt;Car Dealerships&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
+                 &lt;li&gt;&lt;a href="construction.html"&gt;Construction&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
+                 &lt;li&gt;&lt;a href="data-centers.html"&gt;Data Centers&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
+                 &lt;li&gt;&lt;a href="hospitals-healthcare.html"&gt;Hospitals &amp; Healthcare&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
+                 &lt;li&gt;&lt;a href="manufacturing.html"&gt;Manufacturing&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
+                 &lt;li&gt;&lt;a href="marinas.html"&gt;Marinas&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
+                 &lt;li&gt;&lt;a href="mining-quarry.html"&gt;Mining &amp; Quarry&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
+                 &lt;li&gt;&lt;a href="municipalities.html"&gt;Municipalities&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
+                 &lt;li&gt;&lt;a href="power-plants.html"&gt;Power Plants&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
+                 &lt;li&gt;&lt;a href="scrap-metal.html"&gt;Scrap Metal&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
+                 &lt;li&gt;&lt;a href="taxi-companies.html"&gt;Taxi Companies&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
+                 &lt;li&gt;&lt;a href="truck-stops.html"&gt;Truck Stops&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
+               &lt;/ul&gt;
+             &lt;/li&gt;
+             &lt;li&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.foxfuel.com/about/"&gt;About&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
+             &lt;li&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.foxfuel.com/contact/"&gt;Contact&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;'''
+ 
+ def fix_industry_nav(filepath):
+     """Fix nav in an industry page"""
+     try:
+         with open(filepath, 'r', encoding='utf-8') as f:
+             content = f.read()
+         
+         # Pattern to match the nav ul section
+         pattern = r'(&lt;nav class="main-nav"[^&gt;]*&gt;.*?&lt;ul&gt;)(.*?)(&lt;/ul&gt;.*?&lt;/nav&gt;)'
+         
+         def replace_nav(match):
+             nav_start = match.group(1)
+             nav_end = match.group(3)
+             return nav_start + '\n' + canonical_nav + '\n          ' + nav_end
+         
+         new_content = re.sub(pattern, replace_nav, content, flags=re.DOTALL)
+         
+         if new_content != content:
+             with open(filepath, 'w', encoding='utf-8') as f:
+                 f.write(new_content)
+             return True
+     except Exception as e:
+         print(f"Error processing {filepath}: {e}")
+         return False
+ 
+ def main():
+     """Process all industry HTML files"""
+     industries_dir = Path('industries')
+     html_files = list(industries_dir.glob('*.html'))
+     
+     # Exclude index.html as it's already correct
+     html_files = [f for f in html_files if f.name != 'index.html']
+     
+     fixed_count = 0
+     for html_file in html_files:
+         if fix_industry_nav(html_file):
+             fixed_count += 1
+             print(f"Fixed: {html_file}")
+     
+     print(f"\nTotal files fixed: {fixed_count}/{len(html_files)}")
+ 
+ if __name__ == '__main__':
+     main()
+ 
```

</details>

</tool-use>
